metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: explain the formation of a standing wave resulting from the superposition of a travelling wave and its reflection; analyse the formation of standing waves (only those with nodes at both ends is required)

standing_wave_formation.name: Standing Wave Formation
standing_wave_formation.correct: Standing waves form when a travelling wave and its reflection interfere while travelling in opposite directions in the same medium.

a single wave oscillating in place.error: Standing waves require TWO waves, not one.
a single wave oscillating in place.fix: A standing wave is formed by superposition of two waves travelling in opposite directions.
a single wave oscillating in place.action: Draw the incident wave and reflected wave separately, then add them together.

two waves travelling in the same directi.error: Waves must travel in OPPOSITE directions.
two waves travelling in the same directi.fix: The incident wave travels forward; the reflected wave travels backward. They interfere.
two waves travelling in the same directi.action: Visualise a wave hitting a fixed end and bouncing back.

waves that do not travel.error: The component waves DO travel. The pattern appears stationary.
waves that do not travel.fix: Standing waves are made of travelling waves—the interference pattern is what stays still.
waves that do not travel.action: Remember: the NAME is misleading. The waves move; the pattern doesn't.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the pattern with the component waves.
persistent.action: Watch a standing wave animation. Track one wave left-to-right and another right-to-left.

reflection_inversion.name: Reflection at Fixed End
reflection_inversion.correct: A wave reflecting from a fixed end is inverted (180° phase change) but keeps the same frequency and wavelength.

no phase change.fix: A fixed end cannot move, so the wave must invert to satisfy boundary conditions.
no phase change.action: Flick a rope tied to a wall. Watch the pulse flip upside down when it returns.

90° phase change.fix: Inversion means the wave flips completely—that's half a cycle, or 180°.
90° phase change.action: Draw a crest hitting the wall. It returns as a trough. That's 180°.

frequency changes.fix: Reflection changes direction and phase, not frequency or wavelength.
frequency changes.action: Frequency depends on the source. The wall doesn't change how fast you shake the rope.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what happens at a fixed boundary.
persistent.action: Experiment with a slinky. Watch reflections from fixed and free ends. Note the difference.

superposition_principle.name: Superposition Principle
superposition_principle.correct: When waves overlap, their displacements add algebraically at each point to produce the resultant wave.

waves cancel completely.error: Cancellation only occurs at specific points (nodes), not everywhere.
waves cancel completely.fix: Superposition means adding. Sometimes waves add to zero, sometimes to maximum.
waves cancel completely.action: At nodes, displacements always cancel. At antinodes, they add to maximum.

waves pass through unchanged.error: Waves DO interact when they overlap, creating interference patterns.
waves pass through unchanged.fix: While overlapping, displacements combine. After passing, each wave continues unchanged.
waves pass through unchanged.action: Two pulses on a rope: they combine briefly, then separate unchanged.

the larger wave dominates.fix: Superposition is pure addition: +1 + (−1) = 0, not 'bigger wins'.
the larger wave dominates.action: Calculate: if y₁ = 3 cm and y₂ = −3 cm at a point, what is ytotal?

persistent.gap: You're not applying superposition as mathematical addition.
persistent.action: Practice adding wave displacements at 5 different points along a rope.

node_definition.name: Node Definition
node_definition.correct: A node is a point that never moves from equilibrium because destructive interference always occurs there.

point of maximum amplitude.error: That's an antinode, not a node.
point of maximum amplitude.fix: Node = no movement. Antinode = maximum movement.
point of maximum amplitude.action: N for Node, N for No movement. A for Antinode, A for Amplitude maximum.

point where waves meet.error: Waves meet everywhere. Nodes are where they CANCEL.
point where waves meet.fix: Nodes are specific points of permanent destructive interference.
point where waves meet.action: Waves meet at antinodes too. What makes nodes special is zero amplitude.

the ends of the string only.error: Nodes occur at fixed ends AND at regular intervals along the string.
the ends of the string only.fix: Higher harmonics have multiple nodes between the ends.
the ends of the string only.action: Draw the 3rd harmonic. Count the nodes including the ends.

persistent.gap: You're confusing nodes with antinodes or general wave behavior.
persistent.action: Label every node and antinode on standing wave diagrams for harmonics 1-4.

antinode_definition.name: Antinode Definition
antinode_definition.correct: An antinode is a point that oscillates with maximum amplitude due to constructive interference.

point that never moves.error: That describes a node, not an antinode.
point that never moves.fix: Antinodes are where waves ADD constructively, giving maximum movement.
point that never moves.action: Antinode = Anti-node = opposite of a node = maximum movement.

point always at maximum displacement.error: Antinodes OSCILLATE between positive and negative maximum.
point always at maximum displacement.fix: The antinode passes through zero twice per cycle as it oscillates.

point where waves are in phase.error: Being 'in phase' is about timing, not location.
point where waves are in phase.fix: Antinodes are positions of constructive interference, regardless of phase terminology.
point where waves are in phase.action: Focus on what you SEE: maximum oscillation = antinode.

persistent.gap: You don't understand that antinodes oscillate through zero.
persistent.action: Draw an antinode at 4 different times during one period. Show it passing through equilibrium.

node_antinode_spacing.name: Node-Antinode Spacing
node_antinode_spacing.correct: Adjacent nodes and antinodes are separated by λ/4. Adjacent nodes (or adjacent antinodes) are separated by λ/2.

λ/2 between node and antinode.fix: Node to antinode = λ/4. Node to next node = λ/2.
λ/2 between node and antinode.action: Draw one wavelength. Mark nodes and antinodes. Measure the gaps.

λ between adjacent nodes.error: One full wavelength spans TWO node-to-node gaps.
λ between adjacent nodes.fix: Nodes are λ/2 apart. In one λ, there are 2 node-to-node distances.
λ between adjacent nodes.action: Count: λ contains how many half-wavelengths?

depends on the harmonic.error: The spacing in terms of λ is always the same.
depends on the harmonic.fix: Higher harmonics have shorter λ, so shorter absolute spacing—but still λ/4 and λ/2.
depends on the harmonic.action: For ALL harmonics: node-to-antinode = λ/4, node-to-node = λ/2.

persistent.gap: You haven't internalized the standard spacing relationships.
persistent.action: On graph paper, draw standing waves for n=1,2,3. Verify spacing in each case.

harmonic_number.name: Harmonic Number
harmonic_number.correct: The harmonic number equals the number of antinodes in the standing wave, which also equals the number of half-wavelengths that fit in the string length.

number of nodes.fix: For n = 3: 3 antinodes, 4 nodes (including ends). n = antinodes.
number of nodes.action: Draw n=4. Count: 4 antinodes, 5 nodes. n matches antinodes.

number of wavelengths.error: n is the number of HALF-wavelengths, not full wavelengths.
number of wavelengths.fix: n half-wavelengths fit in length L. So λ = 2L/n.
number of wavelengths.action: For n=2: 2 half-wavelengths = 1 full wavelength fits in L.

frequency in Hz.error: n is a counting number, not the frequency value.
frequency in Hz.fix: n = 1, 2, 3... is which harmonic. Frequency = n × f₁.
frequency in Hz.action: The 3rd harmonic (n=3) has f₃ = 3f₁, but n itself is just '3'.

persistent.gap: You're confusing what n represents in standing wave analysis.
persistent.action: Create a table: n, number of antinodes, number of nodes, wavelength (in terms of L).

fundamental_frequency.name: Fundamental Frequency
fundamental_frequency.correct: The fundamental (first harmonic, n=1) is the lowest frequency that produces a standing wave, with wavelength λ = 2L.

highest frequency standing wave.error: The fundamental is the LOWEST, not highest.
highest frequency standing wave.fix: Fundamental = first harmonic = longest wavelength = lowest frequency.
highest frequency standing wave.action: Low frequency = long wavelength. n=1 has λ = 2L, the longest possible.

any frequency that forms a standing wave.error: Only the first harmonic is called the fundamental.
any frequency that forms a standing wave.fix: Fundamental specifically means n=1. Higher harmonics are multiples of it.
any frequency that forms a standing wave.action: The fundamental is special: all other standing wave frequencies are multiples of f₁.

v/L.fix: f₁ = v/(2L) because λ₁ = 2L for the fundamental.
v/L.action: Derive it: v = f₁λ₁ = f₁(2L), so f₁ = v/(2L).

persistent.gap: You don't understand why the fundamental has λ = 2L.
persistent.action: Draw the simplest standing wave with nodes at both ends. What's the longest wavelength possible?

wavelength_formula.name: Standing Wave Wavelength
wavelength_formula.correct: The wavelength of the nth harmonic is λ = 2L/n, where L is the string length and n is the harmonic number.

λ = nL.error: n should be in the denominator, not multiplied.
λ = nL.fix: Higher harmonics have SHORTER wavelengths. λ = 2L/n gives smaller λ for larger n.
λ = nL.action: Test: n=1 gives λ=2L. n=2 gives λ=L. n=3 gives λ=2L/3. Decreasing.

λ = L/n.fix: It's 2L/n, not L/n. The fundamental has λ = 2L, not λ = L.
λ = L/n.action: For n=1: λ = 2L/1 = 2L. Check: one antinode, nodes at ends.

λ = 2nL.error: n in numerator gives LONGER wavelength for higher harmonics—opposite of reality.
λ = 2nL.fix: Higher harmonics = shorter wavelength. n must be in denominator.
λ = 2nL.action: Higher pitch (frequency) means shorter wavelength. Higher n = higher f.

persistent.action: Write λ = 2L/n. Verify for n=1,2,3,4. Does λ decrease as n increases?

frequency_formula.name: Standing Wave Frequency
frequency_formula.correct: The frequency of the nth harmonic is f = nv/(2L), which equals n times the fundamental frequency.

f = v/(nL).error: n should be in the numerator, not denominator.
f = v/(nL).fix: Higher harmonics have HIGHER frequencies. f = nv/(2L) gives larger f for larger n.
f = v/(nL).action: Test: f₂ = 2v/(2L) = v/L. f₁ = v/(2L). So f₂ = 2f₁. Correct.

f = 2nv/L.error: The 2 is in the wrong place.
f = 2nv/L.fix: It's nv/(2L), not 2nv/L. Double-check by substituting n=1.
f = 2nv/L.action: For n=1: f₁ = v/(2L). Your formula gives 2v/L—double the correct value.

f = nλ.error: Confusing the wave equation with the harmonic formula.
f = nλ.fix: Wave equation: v = fλ. Harmonic frequency: f = nv/(2L).
f = nλ.action: These are different relationships. Don't mix them up.

persistent.gap: You're making algebraic errors with the frequency formula.
persistent.action: Derive f = nv/(2L) from v = fλ and λ = 2L/n. Show every step.

wave_speed_independence.name: Wave Speed in Medium
wave_speed_independence.correct: The wave speed in a string depends only on the string's properties (tension and mass density), not on frequency or wavelength.

depends on frequency.error: Speed is independent of frequency in a non-dispersive medium.
depends on frequency.fix: For a string: v = √(T/μ). Frequency and wavelength adjust; speed stays constant.
depends on frequency.action: Higher frequency just means shorter wavelength. v = fλ stays the same.

depends on harmonic number.error: Different harmonics have different f and λ, but same v.
depends on harmonic number.fix: All harmonics travel at the same speed in the same string.
depends on harmonic number.action: Calculate v for the 2nd and 3rd harmonic using v = fλ. They should match.

depends on amplitude.fix: Speed depends on medium properties only: tension and linear density.
depends on amplitude.action: Shake a rope harder (bigger amplitude). Does the wave travel faster? No.

persistent.gap: You're confusing wave speed with other wave properties.
persistent.action: List what affects wave speed in a string (tension, density) vs. what doesn't (f, λ, amplitude).

standing_wave_condition.name: Standing Wave Condition
standing_wave_condition.correct: Standing waves only form when the string length equals a whole number of half-wavelengths.

any wavelength will form a standing wave.error: Only specific wavelengths satisfy the boundary conditions.
any wavelength will form a standing wave.fix: The nodes MUST occur at fixed ends. This restricts allowed wavelengths.
any wavelength will form a standing wave.action: Try fitting λ = 3L into a string. Where do nodes fall? They don't match the ends.

L must equal a whole number of wavelengt.fix: L = nλ/2. The fundamental has L = λ/2 (half a wavelength).
L must equal a whole number of wavelengt.action: Draw n=1: one antinode between two nodes. That's λ/2 fitting in L.

depends on the amplitude.error: Amplitude doesn't determine whether a standing wave forms.
depends on the amplitude.fix: The condition is purely geometric: does λ fit so nodes fall at both ends?
depends on the amplitude.action: Standing wave formation is about wavelength matching length, not amplitude.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the boundary condition requirement.
persistent.action: Draw strings with fixed ends. Try fitting λ = 4L, 2L, L, 2L/3. Which work?
